c74object.name: bach.args
c74object.description: Parses and retrieves the subpatcher's "normal" and attribute-style arguments. bach.args should be used in every subpatch or abstraction accepting arguments, and all the patcher's inlets should be connected to it.

inlet.digest: Bang to output all the arguments

outlet.digest: Bang after all the stored lllls have been output

method.name: bang
method.description: A bang in the rightmost inlet will cause all the patcher arguments to be re-output

method.name: llll
method.description: An llll received in any inlet except the rightmost one (that is, any additional inlet specified through the ins attribute) will be output unchanged from the corresponding outlet, unless before loadbang time - in which case the llll will not be output. If the ins attribute is not present or it is set to 0, then lllls are not accepted in any inlet.

attribute.name: attrs
attribute.description:
An optional set of keywords to be considered as attributes, and therefore output as attribute-style arguments.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: backtick
attribute.description:
When set to 1, if the first element of the "normal arguments" llll is an attribute of any bach object, then a backtick is prepended to it. In this way, it will not be interpreted as an attribute by any bach object you feed it into.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: done
attribute.description:
When set to 1, the message done is output after the last attribute-style argument, just like in patcherargs.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: ins
attribute.description:
The number of llll inlets and outlets. In principle, it should match the number of inlets of the patcher.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: mode
attribute.description:
When set to 1, the "normal arguments" llll is always at least the length of the typed-in arguments. If not enough arguments are specified in the enclosing patcher, the missing ones will be taken from the bach.args' object box. This is especially useful for providing an abstraction with a minimal set of default values.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: nullmode
attribute.description:
When set to 1, null is output if no patcher argument is provided.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

attribute.name: outout
attribute.description:
When set to 1, the out attribute of the containing patcher, if present, as well as any out message received by bach.args, is output as an attribute-style argument.
When set to 0, which is the default, the out attribute of the containing patcher is ignored, as it is assumed that it is meant for a bach.portal object in the same patcher. Also, any out message received by bach.args will be passed to all the bach.portal objects contained in the same patcher of bach.args.
This is a static attribute which can only be set by typing it in the object box.

c74object.discussion: The basic behavior of bach.args is similar to patcherargs's, with improved support for correct synchronization and order preservation of messages and arguments. Everytime the subpatch is loaded, all its arguments and attribute-style arguments are parsed and output, or substituted by specified defaults. If a patch containing nested subpatches or abstractions each with its own instance of bach.args is loaded, the various instances of bach.args will output their arguments in order of depth: that is, the deepest instances will output first, the less deep ones last. The output order of different bach.args objects at the same depth is undefined. bach.args also has a communication mechanism with bach.portal, assuring that each subpatcher's bach.portal is ready when the bach.args object in the same subpatch outputs its arguments. In this way, it is safe for the arguments of the patch to trigger messages to the outside of the patch itself.
